awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the first South Central Topology Conference (SCTC) taking place September 25-26, 2021 at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas. The primary goals of this regional conference include: developing a community of collaborators and experts of varied interests in topology in the region, showcasing a sample of current research directions in topology in the South Central region and beyond it, and communicating developing and exciting results in ways accessible to topologists of all ilks. This conference is timely in light of the research growth in topology in the South Central Region in recent years. 


Modern topology is a large and active field. The conference will be broad in its focus, and will provide a sample of recent research developments in fields such as chromatic and equivariant homotopy theory, higher algebra, symplectic and contact topology, mirror symmetry, and the topology of embedding spaces. The six plenary speakers, Anna Marie Bohmann (Vanderbilt University), Kristen Hendricks (Rutgers University), Robin Koytcheff (University of Louisiana at Lafayette), Jo Nelson (Rice University), Paul VanKoughnett (Texas A&M University), and Abigail Ward (MIT), will give one-hour colloquium-style presentations. There will also be eight short talks given by graduate students and postdocs on a wide range of topics. More information can be found on the conference web page: https://www.hiroleetanaka.com/sctc/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The South Central Topology Conference is an annual regional topology conference series serving the South Central region of the United States. The South Central region is currently an area of active research in topology, with existing or emerging topology groups present at Texas A&M University, Texas Tech University, Texas State University, UT Austin, University of Louisiana, Lafayette, New Mexico State University and others. On the other hand, the South Central region is a vast geographical area, which has many scattered institutions, often accessible only via smaller airports or long drives.
This makes active topology seminars not feasible in many universities in the region and the intention of this annual conference is to provide a venue for recurrent meetings of the topology community. This grant provided funding for the first installment of this conference which took place September 25-26, 2021 at Texas A&M University. This grant supported approximately 25 junior participants.

Intellectual Merit: the main goal of the South Central Topology Conference is to share the latest developments in topology, both within this geographical region and beyond. The conference featured 6 invited speakers who gave presentations on their research in subfields of topology, including category theory, low-dimensional topology,  contact topogy, topological Hochschild homology, symplectic geometry and stable homotopy theory.

Broader Impact: another goal of SCTC is to build the topology community in this geographical region. The conference schedule included plenty of time for discussions and mentoring. The conference featured two contributed talks sessions for postdocs and graduate students with a total of 8 contributed talks. This provided a valuable opportunity for junior participants to present their research.


Last Modified: 04/03/2024
Modified by: Irina Bobkova
